examples: Small businesses have been worst hit by the recession.
Roads in the Tayside region were worst affected by the snow.

meanings: used to emphasize the worst thing, situation, etc.
examples: We had no food or light, but worst of all, we had no water.

meanings: useful and enjoyable, despite needing a lot of effort
examples: She considers teaching a worthwhile career.
The time and expense involved in keeping up to date with all the changes has been worthwhile.
If you need him on this project, you've got to make it financially worthwhile for him.

meanings: used to talk about things that happened often in the past
examples: He would always turn and wave at the end of the street.

meanings: used when you are politely requesting something
examples: I would appreciate it if you could let me know in advance whether or not you will be coming.

meanings: an injury, especially one that is made with a knife or bullet
examples: a gunshot wound
a chest/leg wound
a flesh wound

meanings: to injure someone, especially with a knife or gun
examples: The police chief was badly wounded in the explosion.

meanings: to cover someone with material in order to protect them
examples: She wrapped the baby in a blanket.
He wrapped a towel around his shoulders.

meanings: the part of the body between the hand and the arm
examples: I sprained my wrist playing squash.

meanings: the activity of creating pieces of written work, such as books, stories, poems, etc., or the written work of one person or a group of people
examples: I did a course in creative writing.
She is studying women's writing of the 1930s.

meanings: not considered morally acceptable by most people
examples: Children should be taught that violence is wrong.
It is wrong to tell lies.
What's wrong with having a bit of fun?

meanings: not correctly
examples: It has been said - wrongly - that Americans hate government.

meanings: a photograph that shows the inside of your body
examples: They took an X-ray of his leg.

meanings: a boat with sails and sometimes an engine, used for either racing or travelling on for pleasure
examples: a luxury yacht
a yacht club

meanings: to take a deep breath with your mouth wide open, because you are tired or bored
examples: I can't stop yawning - I must be tired.

meanings: a loud shout
examples: Suddenly there was a loud/great yell from the bathroom.

meanings: to shout something very loudly
examples: Our neighbours were yelling at each other this morning.
The child yelled out in pain.
"Just get out of here!" she yelled.

meanings: again after something has happened or been done many times before
examples: The bus was late yet again.

meanings: again after something has happened or been done many times before
examples: The bus was late yet again.

meanings: used to say that something could be possible although it does not seem likely
examples: You never know - you might win the lottery.

meanings: used to end a formal letter to someone whose name you do not know
examples: Yours faithfully, Katherine Smith

meanings: used to end a formal letter to someone whose name you do not know
examples: Yours faithfully, Katherine Smith

meanings: used to give special emphasis to the subject of the sentence
used when both the subject and object of the verb are 'you', and 'you' is also being used to refer to people generally
examples: If you yourself ever need help, would you know where to get it?
You tell yourself everything's all right but you know it's not really.

meanings: an African animal like a horse with black and white lines
examples: We saw a zebra in the distance.

meanings: a thing for fastening clothes, bags, etc. consisting of two rows of very small parts that connect together
examples: to do up/undo a zip
I can't open my bag - the zip has stuck.
